comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: How quick do palm trees grow ?    I find it hard to believe such a big palm tree at eastwood in 1908

comment.author: 8108294@N05
comment._content: The tree in the centre is a New Zealand Cabbage-tree (Cordyline australis), no more than 20 years old. The palm at left is a Bangalow Palm (Archontophoenix cunninghamiana), of similar age. Fronds at right are a "Cocos Palm" (Syagrus romanzoffiana) - again, no more than 20 years old. -- these estimates assuming adequate watering and good soil conditions. "Eastwood" was presumably the big house after which the suburb was named, as was commonly the case around Sydney, and most such were built well back into the 19th century.

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: A view of 'Eastwood House' c1907 (from Ryde Council): www.ryde.nsw.gov.au/About+Ryde/Historic+Ryde/Historic+Bui... and a recent view by Marist Brothers College, Eastwood (current owner of the house): home.mce.nsw.edu.au/_College_History.htm
